ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] [PROPOSAL] Version numbering
ygData.msgSnippet: ... We could do this too.  Included below are some links that discuss the versioning used by the linux kernel team. So, odd numbered MINOR (or mode ) numbers

Gordon Mohr wrote:

>Another convention that seems to have worked well for other
>projects (linux) is to use odd minor version numbers to track
>working/developer code, and jump to even minor version numbers
>for all actual releases.
>
>Thus as soon as release 0.2 happens, the working branch (HEAD)
>is considered 0.3. At some point 0.3.X becomes good enough to
>"release", so it becomes 0.4, and the working branch jumps to 0.5,
>etc.
>
>  
>
We could do this too.  Included below are some links that discuss the 
versioning used by the linux kernel team.

So, odd numbered MINOR (or 'mode') numbers are development releases 
(0.1.0, 0.3.0, 2.1.0, etc.).  Using this mechanism, we would do w/o the 
jakarta '-dev' and '-rcX' qualifiers.  We could also put off branching 
till absolutely necessary just tagging HEAD at release points only 
branching when we want to fix a bug going against a particular release 
(John Erik Halse suggested this).  A branch could be done at any point 
in a release's life but we might still call it by the releases' 
MAJOR.MINOR component anyways though we might be bug fixing version 
MAJOR.23.12 to make release MAJOR.23.13.

St.Ack

http://www.cs.helsinki.fi/cgi-bin/linuxversion/
http://www.ussg.iu.edu/hypermail/linux/kernel/9804.3/0241.html

>- Gordon
